awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Functional Genomics Research for Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the Jackson Laboratory (JAX), located in Bar Harbor, ME, will support the training of 12 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. Undergraduates will conduct original research in mammalian functional genomics with a faculty mentor at JAX. Student research will expand their basic understanding of how an organism's genome determines its development and biological function. To prepare for genomics research, students will have access to online modules prior to and during their fellowship, will complete workshops in computational methods and bioinformatics, and will attend seminars to prepare them for graduate education and a career in genomics. Students will increase their self-confidence and build their network within a learning community that is part of the long-standing JAX Summer Student Program, including a shared on-campus residential program. The REU Site recruits undergraduate students at all levels. The goal is to develop a diverse community of learners including individuals from groups underrepresented in science, such as racial and ethnic minorities, people with disabilities, and people with a significant socioeconomic or educational disadvantage, including first-generation college students. 

It is anticipated that a total of 12 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. Students trained in genomics will become more versatile, be able to work in teams with the potential for higher impact research. REU students at JAX will become better communicators and more aware of the ethical, legal, and social responsibilities of genomics scientists. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the JAX program is available by visiting https://www.jax.org/ssp, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Linda Hicke, linda.hicke@jax.org) or the Program Director (Michael McKernan, michael.mckernan@jax.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site award to The Jackson Laboratory (JAX), located in Bar Harbor, ME, supported the training of 36 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2023 (skipping a year in 2020 due to the COVID-related public health emergency in Maine). Undergraduate students from 30 different institutions across the country performed original research in mammalian functional genomics in the laboratory of a faculty mentor at JAX. The REU program at JAX was designed around three goals:

  1. Providing an authentic and mentored research experience - Each participant worked on an independent, hypothesis-driven, mentored research project in functional genetics and genomics alongside an experienced JAX mentor. Projects were matched to the student's personal interests and goals. Student research expanded their basic understanding of how an organism's genome determines its development and biological function. Students participated in work in the labs of 24 different JAX scientists.
  2. Promoting diversity in science - The JAX REU Site in Functional Genomics, with a Living Learning Community as a critical backdrop, develops skills around student agency and self-efficacy important for persistence in research careers. During this program, we worked to foster a diverse community of learned made of individuals with different family and educational circumstances including 16 (44%) individuals from groups underrepresented in science, such as racial and ethnic minorities, people with disabilities, and people with a significant socioeconomic or educational disadvantage, including first-generation college students. In this scientific community students report that they are able to learn more about and to see their place in that community. They tell us that their science benefits from conversations and collaborations with the scientists around them – both at the lab and those with whom they live.
  3. Encouraging careers in science and promoting lifelong scientific literacy  - JAX provides an environment that exposes the students to a wide range of research careers, seminars and interactions with members of the JAX community outside of the individual research labs.  We also provide training in other critical aspects of research such as ethical, legal, and social issues in science, presentation skills, foundational coding in R, and professional networking.

 

A summative evaluation at the end of each year measured how well the program meets its desired short-term outcomes:

  1. Students will have a broader perspective on the nature of scientific research and its place in society REU participants report that the program broadened their perspective of the role scientific research plays in changing the world around us and that workshops on ethical, legal, and social issues in research were informative and useful.
  2. Students will have a broader perspective on how scientific research fits into their personal educational and career goals  Of the 36 REU participants, 4 (11%) will be undergraduates in the fall of 2024; 19 (53%) will be enrolled in a graduate program in the biological sciences, 2 (6%) will be in medical school, with one of those among the 3 (11%) with MPH degrees. One of our alumni will be a Fulbright-Nehru scholar in public health in Fall 2024.  Two students have started careers as clinical research coordinators and one as a software engineer.
  3. Students will experience personal changes that will enable them to reach full potential as students and professionals. REU participants report the program increased their knowledge of mammalian genetics and genomics research, helped them to develop laboratory skills and techniques as well as their understanding of how knowledge is constructed. They also report that their REU summer increased their ability to integrate theory and practice, their readiness for more demanding research and their tolerance for the obstacles faced in the research process.
